column4: We have come to the gardens to see every season. The free tour is a must. If you don't take the tour you miss so much. Very well laid and thought out, very deep in culture, amazing and beautiful. Take the time to spend here and take the tour, otherwise you may be disappointed.

They were renovating the pond so they cut the price in half which was fair. (Wish hotels that were renovating made a similar offer). I caught up to the tour which helped to understand the garden better. There is a public park which is part of the same place and free. It was totally closed for pond renovation. It should...

We visited while the Garden is undergoing some repair, while the pond was not full, you could still see all of the beauty and pride the caretakers of the Garden have. It was really lovely and educational. Worth the trip to Chinatown!
A lovely garden that is pretty typical of other Chinese gardens. If you are passing and have an our to spare, then this is not a bad way to do it

A marvelous presentation of the botanical culture transformed us from the street of a big city to another time and place. Close to Chinatown and some great lunchtime restaurants too. What a great day out!

No matter what the season is this a wonderful pay-for-use city garden. With authentic architecture and materials imported from China, this meditative tea garden is a place to come and spend some quiet time. This is the first scholars garden to be built outside of China. Based on a Suzhou Chinese garden, it shares the same plants as you find...

We walked to go to this garden only to find it closed and when we peeked through the gate in the back it looked filthy. The pond has dried up and there was filth at the bottom. There was a sign saying they were charging an entrance fee. Please walk to the back and peep through the gate before getting...
I went there for a night event and free entrance for me because my friend got tickets. I feel very relaxing while I wAs there. I would definitely go back during daytime.
The beautiful garden was built by master Chinese gardeners and it is an oasis in the middle of the city. It also has some cultural and historical exhibits.
A garden walk that brings you to a quiet peace filled space. A bit out of the way, but well worth a quiet walk through the garden.

It's beautifully landscaped and very peaceful place. It's open to the public and no admission fee. If you are to visit Chinatown, I would recommend to stop by at this garden. It won't take , much of your time since this place is small.

This is a very good match to the garden of the same name in China. Every details has been done with care. Make sure you have the historical information. There are special ceremonies and presentations that make this place even more special.
Very beautiful gardens in Chinatown with jasmine tea served at the end of the tour. A very enjoyable experience.

My visit to the garden was very enjoyable. On arrival I was advised a tour was due to start so I waited around. The tour was very informative and I learned a lot about yin/yang, the idea of balance and how it is reflected in every aspect of the garden. It was also interesting finding out how the garden was...

The Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Chinese Garden is surprisingly quiet and tranquil considering that it is right in downtown Vancouver. There are little paths along the Bamboo trees that you can walk around. There is a pond with some nice views to take pictures or just relax.
I have been here a few times for the garden and the pond. The pond is well recreated down to the color. There are tons of koi in the pond. One side of the garden requires a donation.
Very very interesting garden; went in the fall and would love to go back in the spring when the trees are in bud;

When recently visiting Vancouver's Chinatown (or the few things that are left of it) we felt uplifted when we ventured into the garden as the surroundings were so desolate and run down. The garden was a still haven of contemplation and rest, beautifully laid out and maintained, with views opening up after every turn. The iced over lake and the...
As a contrast to the botanical garden, we visited the Chinese garden. It was very peaceful and extremely beautiful and serene.

Going into this place really felt like you were leaving the city behind. Luckily got there just in time for the tour- which I would recommend because it's easy to over look a lot of little things in the garden without knowing what they mean. Lovely to walk around though- and bigger than it looks at first sight!

One of Vancouver's premier attractions. It's worth taking a tour to learn about the significance of the gardens and its features. Afterwards go for lunch at one of the little places in China Town, like the New Town Bakery, or one of the many restaurants in Gastown.

Wonderful garden to while away an hour or two in Vancouver, especially in the summertime. As a solo traveler I found this to be the perfect place to relax and decompress without feeling like you have to keep ordering coffee. Only complaint is I wish it were a little bigger!

Dr. Sun-Yat Sen park and garden. Located in China Town Vancouver, right by the gate to Chinatown and world famous thinnest The Sam Kee Building. Even surroundings of this location is spectacular, but as soon as you enter the park itself, the whole vibe changed immediately, and feel of real oriental place will win over western culture!Dr. Sun Yat...
We spent only 10 minutes there because it is a very small garden and it is very crowed. It is nice though if you don't have much time .
A peaceful place to walk around enjoy a nice cup of Chinese tea and beautiful photo opportunities in the snow.

We visited the garden on a cold, wintry crisp clear day. It cost us C$12 with our Vancouver Attraction Passport Coupon book. The ticket included a free informative guided tour. The garden was opened in 1986 and was the first Classical Chinese Garden built outside China.The gardens traditionally were used by scholars for study, contemplation and writing. This one...

This place is a must! The first Authentic Chinese garden outside of China. Its beautiful in all 4 seasons and the free tour is really helpfuland enhances the vist so much more i definitely recommend spending your time for the tour. It felt like i wasnt in Vancouver anymore but in China. This place is SO beautiful if i had...
Not a huge space, but well worth a look while exploring Vancouver's China Town area. Rotating festivals and events might make your visit more exciting - check ahead of time!

We both really enjoyed the tour of the gardens. Our guide was incredibly knowledgeable and pointed out loads of interesting design features and their relevance to Chinese culture. Admittedly the surrounding area of Chinatown is now quite run down but the gardens are still well worth a visit.
Its small, but reminds me of gardens I saw in China. It incorporates the use of natural stones and pools as forms of landscape design

This is a very authentic re-creation of a Ming Dynasty scholars house, using specially imported materials from China. The guided tour was excellent and very informative, you will miss a lot of the interesting details if you do not take the tour. We sat and took in the beauty and tranquility of the place for some time after the tour....

I'd been advised people with a love of Classic Chinese garden design and moreover an understanding of Feng Shui would find this attraction worthwhile. I appreciated the beautiful symmetry of water, plants and buildings yet its compact size and narrow pathways detracted from my experience. A guide was on hand explaining to a large group the elements and meaning of...

A guided tour of the garden comes with your entry fee. I would highly recommend going on the tour. I learned so much from guide that I would not have known otherwise and it made the garden even that much more special. Beautiful and amazing garden!
A beautiful outdoor setting. Plant life and man made buildings both harmonize with nature. Beautiful even in rain.

My friend and I were on the hop on/hop off Vancouver bus and decided to stop here - absolutely lovely place. Great for photos - it's great to see all the natural beauty of the gardens with the city backdrop.We spent about 3 hours here - but that did include lots of photographing and drawing!Great place for couples...

I visited Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Park while walking through China Town. I truly enjoyed the solitude of this park. The Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Garden is located adjacent to this park. Admission to the garden was $12 per person, but entrance to the park was free.The park was tranquil and lovely, with ponds and koi, trees, plants, and Chinese pagodas....

I presume this garden will be lovely again after the construction works are completed but in May 2016 there were many areas closed for the public. We also felt that there should have been a reduction on the price because of the many closed areas. We tried a tour with a guide but her English was so bad we could...

This place is a very great place to see an explore Chinese culture, and structure. The price is really fare considering it is in Vancouver where land it is becoming very expensive and this area might be under treat to disappear if you don't support it. You can have amazing pictures, time to relax, read a book.

As soon as I arrived the garden, I told myself it is paradise. the plants, trees and flowers are really beautiful. the garden has different yards which have been designed differently.the garden so quiet, delightful and peaceful. The carved windows, the two sided embroidered silk of hundred butterflies, short bridges, red fish swimming in unique designed pools. An art class...
Beautifully manicured small garden area. The 'guide' was funny but very knowledgeable. He brought a new perspective to the principles of ying and yang. .

Beautiful and tranquil garden in the heart for Vancouver. You can either stroll through the outside garden for free or pay to go into the main gardens, free guided tour included. Nice place to sit and reflect.

One of better Chinese gardens outside of China. I particular enjoyed how it's named after Dr. Sun Yat-Sen.It's right inside of Vancouver China Town. Do check it out if you have time. But I don't think it's a "must see."
These are beautiful & tranquil gardens - you will feel that you have been transported - it was crowed on a Sun., but it did not feel that there were many people in the gardens

You have the option of either paying to go into the closed portion of this traditional garden for a fee, which will include a guided tour by a docent, or walking for free into the other side (within the same walls) where you can view the ponds, rocks, and Chinese plants (bamboo, etc. and visit a gift shop. We did...
This garden was very close to the Anthropology Museum and was a wonderful, serene Japanese Garden. Lots of authentic design elements. One of the nicest I've seen.
The surrounding area is not so much but these gardens are a real delight - well laid out and with beautiful niches all around - water, trees, chinese buildings, all very lovely

The entrance fee is CAD 12 and regrettably not all the garden sections were open. Inside the architecture was okay but possibly dissapointing if you have travelled through Taiwan and China. It was okay.

A great destination of relaxation and reflection in any weather right in the downtown core. I've lived in Vancouver for 16 years and stop in here often for a place to take the kids to look the KOI or to read on a bench
It's a small, lovely, serene garden located in Chinatown. Even with the stormy weather, the garden was well groomed and quiet.

If you are interested in design and architecture, and yearn for a calm spot in the city, this is the place for you. If you are a traditional avid gardener, maybe not. There is a free public garden outside the main garden walls. Go inside for a $10 fee and free tour and be delighted. All materials - wood, rock,...
Maybe it was the time of year, but we were not impressed. We went because it is on the List of things to see while in Vancouver but we found it lacking.

My family all enjoyed our visit to the gardens. The tour guide was informative and we all loved his sense of humor. We enjoyed the beauty of the gardens, the architecture and how yin/yang influence design.
A must see in the middle of the hustle and bustle. Right behind Chinatown. Must visit the gift shop as well, which offers beautiful art!

We were eager to see this as many in our group are avid gardeners, but all agreed: this was not worth the time or money.Part of the garden is closed and other sections are in need of repair.The guide we had was odd and difficult to understand. We skipped away while he wasn't looking.

A well maintained garden within the Chinatown and strategically located. It could be better if the plants can be diversified to red, yellow, orange colors representing the Fall season. Do be aware of its opening hours.
We highly enjoyed the 10:30 garden tour with Fred. The adjoining park abuts Chinatown, so you can complete the experience with some Chinese food for lunch or dinner.
This is a nice, if small, bit of tranquility in the middle of a rather bustling area of the city. Not a "must-see" but worth a quck look.

After a walk through bustling Gastown this garden provides a little oasis of quiet enjoyment. I especially appreciate the placement and shapes of the many rocks.They put that garden in a special class.
Lovely Chinese gardens in the middle of China Town. Very restful and you can take a free guided tour of the gardens which is very informative.

Nice clean manageable small park good for a tranquil quite and even meditative respite from the busy modern environ. Brings one back to the old simple times.Every visit in Vancouver - it is a good time for relaxation and reflection and rest especially after shopping and a full stomach.

Those familiar with Feng Shui will get special enjoyment out of this special park. The first of it's kind in Canada, it was built using Ming Dynasty techniques which are said to create serenity. Certainly works for me every time I come by. Busy day? Full after a meal in Chinatown? Drop by here and sit for a while -...

A nice and unique Chinese garden on the fringe of Chinatown. We visited here on our first Vancouver trip and enjoyed the garden. On our second visit we noticed the changes and growth in the plants. Very relaxing and recommended.

This was a nice little oasis on the outskirts of Vancouver's Chinatown (which is pretty funny actually, since most of the new, sleek high-rises in all the trendy areas are also now owned by the Chinese). A quiet, peaceful and very clean little oasis. There's a visitor center and gift shop you can go thru for a fee, or you...
The gardens are free and you can spend a few minutes or a few hours in this 15th Century Chinese garden
This is a great garden to walk in and walk out. It will only take you a few minutes to go through it.

Loved the tour and the guide. So informative. Watched the fish being called and feed Chinese style. Learnt how the gardens were made from Chinese materials brought from China and crafted by Chinese people. So many traditions kept in this building. Stunning. Loved the tea afterwards.
Very nice park full of Chinese garden culture.Free access, sometimes used by Chinese families for wedding photographs.Big koi carps in the pond.Not a lot of seating areas however.

A wonderful classic Chinese Garden. 45 minute tour if you are interested gives the history of how it was built and the philosophy behind the garden.Good place even on rainy day since most of the walk ways are covered and there is plenty of seating for those that are slow walkers. This is a free to visit and has the gardens as well as the museum. The gardens are lush (large bamboos) and there is a huge pond with huge gold fish and many ducks! It is a nice break for the hustle outside its gates. It is in a safe neighbourhood and if you have the time, worth visiting. Of...

We joined a soft spoken but informative docent for a tour of this urban oasis. She explained the concepts of balance inherent in Chinese garden design. Cultural/educational/garden/peaceful.Be aware that the public park flows right next to the garden--no fee for the park, but fee for the Classical Garden/Walled House.Near a drug use area.

It was actually in a seedy feeling part of town. The attraction was smaller than I expected. I would not recommend it. The only plus was the walk along the river from Granville Island to get there, and then we ended up in Gastown.

Walked here during a morning from downtown Vancouver. The area it is situated in (Chinatown) is quite run down and you go through poor areas with lots of homeless shelters and people. I was on my own and was a little wary but it was all good and so worth it when I got to the garden. A little peace...

We waited for the guided tour which was most informative and made the garden come alive. Designed as a traditional 'scholars house' with all the materials brought over from China and assembled by a team of specialists from China. A calm wonderful space to enjoy and linger in. Watching the Carp come to the sound of a gong for feeding...

The garden was beautiful, in a not so wonderful part of Vancouver. My favorite parts were the authentic buildings, the mosaic grounds, and the fun 'quizzes' attached to Chinese lanterns. There was a show of the tiny shadow boxes (see pictures) that we enjoyed - very inspiring! Peaceful and tranquil-much needed after accidentally coming upon a block of heroism users...

This garden sits in the middle of Vancouver Chinatown. It is a heaven in the heart of the town rush.The gidded tour was fantastic, providing lots of information on the symbolism without which the visit would be a little swallow. I'd definitely recommend to go and spend roughly an hour (or more ;) ) there.
It's not for everyone! It's a goodChoice for sunny and hot days, on summer and spring! Great place to seat down and chill!
This is a calm little walled park in the middle of the city. Nice place to visit and stroll through. You can get some interesting photos of Chinese garden foregrounds with skyscraper backgrounds.

We only went to the public gardens but there is enough to see there without needing to go through to the private monk gardens. Cost was $14 per adult or $13 with HOHO bus coupon. 1/3 acre garden, it is the first ever chinese garden built outside China. Guided tours given hourly by volunteer. The volunteer is very passionate about explaining how and why certain plants are where they are and the meaning behind the gardens. Lovely peaceful place. There is also a 2/3...
If you go beyond the public area into the private garden (which costs $7) you can see a beautiful chinese garden laid out as a duplicate of one in China including authentic stones etc. Beautiful.
Known as one of Vancouver's must see sits. The garden are beautiful and maintain is a great way, nevertheless this is a small place and the tickets are expansive.
Enjoyed the quiet and serene atmosphere of this quaint garden in the middle of the city. Be sure to check out the monstrous sized goldfish in the pond.
The guide was able to explain how and why things were planted and arranged in specific ways. The actual architectural matters used were specifically produced in China for this garden.

Really enjoyed this visit. There was a tour already underway when we arrived but we dipped in and out and joined it from time to time. The guide really brought the place alive. Great feeling of peace and serenity especially in view of some of the seediness nearby and the hot jasmine tea was a lovely bonus. There is a...

We came across this garden while walking around Chinatown so popped in for a look. It is a small garden but nicely laid out and definitely worth a few minutes of your time if you are in this area and want some peace and quiet.
We visited this venue since we were in Chinatown. It was OK, but nothing special. Don't make a special effort to come here.

The park is free and very beautiful but going next door and paying the admission price turned out to be a fascinating experience. The volunteer guide was very knowledgeable with an obvious passion for the work there. Learning the thoughts behind the selection and positioning of each rock, tree and paver made it a lasting memory.
After walking and sightseeing all day, this was a welcome respite from the day. Very beautiful, calming with a beautiful history.

Its well worth taking the tour rather than just looking ate the free public area. The guide explains the philosophy behind the gardens as well as their history and information about the designer/constructors.
So much to see and do-recommend hop on off bus- drivers very knowledgeable/Stanley park/ harbour trip/gas town and china town
Beautiful garden, but very small - definitely not worth the price of admission. You can see a good portion of the gardens from the park next door which is completely free.

visit both and stay for tea. The gardens are very extensive, a real surprise in the middle of the city, and in a renewed China Town. We went to visit the garden on a hot sunny day. It was peaceful, cool and very pretty. The guided tour was very informative and the gift shop full of delightful things.
This is a lovely space, a must see in Chinatown. So peaceful and pretty and quiet. Chinatown is a great neighborhood to spend some time in.

I took a hop on hop off trolley to the Chinese Gardens and I was disappointed with the gardens. It was very old and overgrown. I walked in and around in less than 10 minutes and had to wait a further 10 minutes for the next trolley to come back and pick me up.
Certainly not the best Chinese Gardens I've seen. It needs some maintenance and a bit of a clean! Disappointed.
It's free to enter these tranquil & beautiful gardens, with the backdrop of the Vancouver city skyscrapers. Lovely place to take a stroll or relax.

We visited in the late afternoon on a Wednesday. There was parking in a multi-story garage just to the east of the garden.The main garden area consists of a perimeter wall enclosing various pathways, tress, shrubs, and a large koi/fish pond. There is a pavilion adjacent to the pond also. The garden is not expansive, but the paths are...
If you are going to China town then stop to see garden. Admission is free. It really is not worth a special trip.
The garden was fascinating. It was very oriental and gave you the feeling of being part of an ancient place in China. It peaceful and tranquil. A good place to start your tour for the day.
Pretty garden. Fair number of homeless including one aggressive guy who was doing a lot of yelling which interfered with the tranquility.
We joined a tour, which is included in the admission price. It was very informative and taught us things we otherwise wouldn't have known if we'd just gone walking around on our own.

If you are going to China town do call in , it's well laid out but it really is not worth a special trip, so if you are in the area call in, the gardens are free.I would not recommend a special visit, the pond had huge carp but the water is a bit dirty and had drink cans...

These gardens are authentic. Everything was brought from China and a typical Chinese garden was created. Take the tour as a part of the garden is free but the guide tells so much about how it was built and the Chinese culture and reasons for Chinese gardens.

The price of admission includes a tour. Tours start at the top of every hour. You may want to check out two tours as different tour guides provide different knowledge of the structures. Tours are 45 minutes so allow two hours.

Beautiful and peaceful respite from the heat and the busyness of the city. Very beautiful gardens. Something we discovered is there is a small part of the garden free to the public.it is not as exquisite as the paid part, but, nonetheless, free and shady and quiet.We didn't take the tour but found volunteers very willing to chat. The...
We had a delightful tour guide who provided us with fascinating insights into the development of Chinese Gardens & the meanings behind the various motifs. Beautiful gardens.

Overall, we had a wonderful visit to this absolutely stunning, classical Chinese garden in the midst of Chinatown. We strongly urge visitors to start with a guided tour of the garden! Sent a while in these gardens. Attractively laid out. Very busy though. Go early if you are going to take pictures.
this is a place to meditate and take a walk around the pond, look at fish, enjoy some quiet time and do some shopping as well
Quiet, short detour in Chinatown. You can do a small tour that includes tea time and a authentic Chinese garden, but the free garden is also pretty in itself.

An unplanned visit as by chance we passed the gardens on a walk through the Chinatown area. For a small admission charge we found the gardens extremely well presented - staff were readily available to give talks plus numerous picture opportunities.

I have been to this venue twice on visits to Vancouver, once alone and once with my wife, and I enjoyed it both times. Thsi is in the middle of China town which is very old and very ordinary.The garden itself is small but not bd.Ther is a private part which has an admission fee and can do a guided tour which we didnt do.They offer free Chinese free as part of the admission fee.The public side also small but not bad with soem...

This is a beautiful Classical Chinese garden and YVR is so lucky to have this gem! Make sure you take one of the tours so that you really get to appreciate all the nuances of this place, there is so much attention to detail that you won't know about unless you take the tour. Enjoy it!
The garden is lovely and the docents give lots of good information about how Chinese scholars lived. Well worth seeing.
Situated in Chinatown, these gardens are a peaceful break from the rush of the city. Has walking paths, pools with Koi fish and displays.

This was one of the highlights of our Vancouver trip. We visited both the paid and the free section and it's definitely worth paying to go to the nicer one. We went on the tour and was't impressed. However, the park is serene and extremely well put together. Take a book and relax for a morning or afternoon here!

The garden and park are in the heart of downtown Vancouver, but many locals may not have even heard of it. I'm writing this review in hope that they will. It is such a special and peaceful place. Unfortunately it was raining despite that we really appreciated the guided visit. It is a good way to know more about that culture. It was very interisting and also funny especially drawing with water.

While walking through Chinatown we came across this beautiful garden. It was weird how it was so peaceful in the core of a busy city. The gardens are kept up very well. This place is ideal for taking some excellent pictures that are different than your typical big city pictures.
On an uncomfortably hot and humid day, after disembarking from ou cruise ship, we visited the Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden
Walked though it quickly because it was super hot and humid the day we went. If you'd like some calm from the city bussle, go to this garden.

Smaller than I expected, but a lovely tranquil place nonetheless. The ponds with fish, the bonsai trees, the bamboo are all lovely. I didn't actually take the tour as it didn't need to be necessary, and I was in a bit of a hurry, but that might have enhanced the experience. Not bad for a lazy stroll if you are...

I had read a lot about this garden and was looking forward to the visit. It is located in a dingy part of the city and is a lot smaller than I expected. It is a bit rundown and probably covers about 2 tennis courts. It is therefore very expensive to enter, we tried to be very contemplative about the...

Part of Vancouver's Chinatown, we anticipated a relatively quick visit and emerged many hours later (if in a rush: 1.5 to 2 hours including the tour should work): this is not just any garden, but the first scholars garden built outside China, completed by experts in 1986. The garden is named in honour of Sun Yat-Sen (also called 'father of...
A few hours spent here taking in the sights and sounds of the gardens and having a cup of traditional chinese tea to the music in the grand hall is a welcome change from the busy shops.

This is typical of a Chinese garden. In the middle of a city, you go in and there is a calm atmosphere. It Has a lovely small park. If you want to do the actual garden there is a fee, but again Peaceful and relaxing . Doesn't take too long to go around.

If you go to this garden, pay for the extra entry price and go when there is a tour. You will learn so much about the ins and outs of traditional building practice. Wonderful Garden next to the old Chinatown. Probably one of the most beautiful urban garden in North America. The area around the garden is not the nicest but this place is a must to be seen...beauty, relaxation, peace. This old Park with a small lake, a Pagoda and a footpath aroundgives you a break from the hectic. A Chinese Souvenir shop and a Museum ( entrance fee ) is also on the compound.
The garden is lovely, but the well defined tour gave fascinating insights to the culture and artistry that make up a classical garden.

It's a cute traditional Chinese garden. Very small compare to Yu garden in Shanghai, but same vibe. If you are already in Chinatown shopping at El Kartel or chilling at Matchstick roaster, it's very close by and you should pop in from the side entrance.

We visited the Dr. Sun-Yat Classical Chinese Garden following an entry in the "1000 Places To See Before You Die" book. It is in a run down area and whilst the garden was free, the entrance fee to the building was overpriced. Even if free it was not worth the effort of visiting. Beautiful architecture embellished by carefully prepared gardens. Cannot be more Chinese than this. Everywhere you look is a picture to take. The guided tour is very informative about the Chinese culture.

we have been here several times in the past and each time it seems to need more attention. It is beautiful, but it needs some sprucing up. Expecting beautifully manicured gardens, aesthetic landscapes with unusual floral arrangements, this venue was disappointing. Stark exhibits, less than interesting flora, the gardens are wanting.

Visited while traversing the city on the "Hop on Hop off" bus and although the public area seemed a little less than we expected we moved onto the guided tour behind the public area. You can approach the gardens in two ways. For those culture vultures, there is a tour included in the entrance fee that, as well as the Chinese tea on offer, will satisfy any thirst for knowledge, from the artful building practises to the placement of items and their significance. The gardens are also for those who just wish to wander...
This place is small and worth to see it but be aware that you have to pay to visit the other side which is the house.The garden is beautiful and follow one of my pictures.
Very briefly visited this eye catching attraction. Worth a walk through but not worth going out of your way for.

Lovely gardens, and some really interesting feng shui ideas. The park is free and very nice, with turtles and carp in the water. The gardens are very expensive to visit, and in my opinion, overpriced. The area is not good at all - Chinatown in Vancouver has sadly become a haven for homeless and drugs, and can at times be...

This place was a great find. Some fifty of so craftsmen and tons of materials were brought in from China to build this very special place. Everything except plant life was brought over. Was asked to do a photo shoot in the gardens and it fast became my favorite place. Lots of history in the gardens. Beautiful architecture to photography, the sights were stunning. We were taken up to the Ting which was gorgeous. If you want to go back in history, be sure to check out the Gardens!

It is a very quiet place amidst busy city in the China Town, Vancouver. The jade green pond with golden fish is a beautiful place to spend time leisurely. This garden was the most peaceful and serene place I've ever visited. The architecture was amazing, the grounds were beautiful, and the guide was very knowledgeable. This garden is a must see in Vancouver.

I always make a point to walk through this garden while I'm in the neighbourhood. Only visited Park next to Garden which is free and accessible from Chinese Cultural Centre. Lovely waterlillies, turtles and giant carp.

Went with expectations of seeing a beautiful place, but left after two hours with a greater understanding of the Chinese culture and importance of characteristics of the garden. There are so many life lessons built into each area. Take the tour and then relax on some of benches. Great experience!

We found the garden a wonderful contrast to the endless blocks of apartments and offices of the Downtown which overlook it. We were fortunate to join a guided tour which greatly added to our understanding and enjoyment of our visit.

This is a lovely tribute to Dr. Sun Yat Sen, a little bit of China in the middle of a Canadian city. It is tranquil and beautiful. In fact, as I approached and walked across the courtyard that led to the opening, I had distinct flashback to my visit to China several years ago. If you have the time, this...
